docs.lead_paragraph: IN this era of heroic therapies for advanced heart disease - starting with $30,000 coronary bypass operations and proceeding through $250,000 heart transplants and multimillion-dollar artificial heart implants - it's hard to focus public attention on the fact that most of the people who need such costly treatments could have avoided the disease in the first place had they lived healthier lives. Last week, however, while the latest artificial heart recipient continued to make front-page news, preventive measures briefly captured the spotlight. Americans were told by a panel of experts that most need to change their diets to reduce the amount of cholesterol circulating in their blood. This warning was directed, in part, to millions of adults who have been told by their physicians that their cholesterol levels are ''normal.'' Levels often considered normal in this country are too high to be healthy, the panel said, and have helped make heart disease far and away the nation's leading killer.
